Description: Egyptian terracotta female figure with hair worn up, with earrings. Mould-made, following Tanagra style. Head only. White coating with traces of red on hair. Pale orange-brown fabric with salmon core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

2nd century BC parallel from Egypt (Fischer 1994, no.1253) and example found at Memphis with similar hair style (Petrie Memphis III pl.44.163). Gutch suggests this (probably one of Gutches nos 99-101e, found at site no. 38) example's hair style is typical of c.200BC (Hogarth 1899, pl. 12.98). Alexandrian or (less likely) Hellenistic Greek import. Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-Römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Petrie, W.M.F. 1910. Meydum and Memphis volume III. London, School of Archaeology in Egypt.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 84, nos 99-101)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.407) (Phase 1)
